last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
The combat is boring, there is no challenge.
The only thing it does is slow you down, or separate you from your cargo.
BTs don't move, substantially reducing the suspense, rendering the threat almost comedic.
All the player needs to do is to walk around them. The only skill being tested is patience.
If caught, the player just needs to spam the shake-off button, which is just pinnacle gameplay right there.
With mini bosses, Sam can either escape at a slug's pace, or throw his piss, shit, and blood at the boss, over and over again.
There is no dodging, parrying, timing, spacing mechanics, nor any problem solving.
Just maintain distance and throw bodily discharge at the enemy until it's dead.
And guess what? The enemy HP doesn't even reset on player death!
The challenges presented to the player are just artificial and time-wasting.

The building mechanic is simply placing down a foundation, and tediously dragging materials to the foundation.
Once the road, bridge, or zipline is placed, the walking and the BTs can be skipped entirely.
Players who have built infrastructure won't elect to walk ever again, revealing the truth that the gameplay itself is boring.
Kojima drones who enjoy waiting for Sam to traverse over ziplines, and then listening to boring NPC monologue, over and over again, are deluding themselves.

The value of art is subjective.
But you can't just shit on a canvas and call it art.
The pretentiousness of Kojima is beyond insufferable and sets a terrible precedent for the video game industry.
The world of Death Stranding lacks variety.
Missions are Ubisoft tier copy and paste.
Buildings and rooms are identical.
Most of the story is delivered through journal entry exposition dumps.
The combat is repetitive.
All of this is a reflection of Kojima's low effort and creativity.
Celebrity cameos are not a substitute for gameplay, and won't be enough to save this dumpster fire of a "game".

Death Stranding sucks.
Kojima is a hack and a fraud.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
More common responses:
>Just turn off online features
And ignore one of the game's main selling points? Nice own goal.
>It's not unusual for films to depict ordinary experiences attainable in real life. Why should video games be any different?
Video games are unique because they are interactive, they have gameplay.
It should therefore be every game designer's prerogative to prioritize fun gameplay before anything else, to fully utilize the medium.
Otherwise the game would be no different from a film - which Death Stranding clearly should have been.
>What about sports games? I can play sports in real life.
Sports games actually do provide the unattainable for most people.
The mechanics of the sport is simplified by reducing complex body motion / hand-eye coordination with keyboard/controller interaction.
The player does not experience fatigue, injury, and can be as strong/fast as the game will allow.
On the other hand, walking is a trivial activity.
The weight of the cargo, or lack of (due to exoskeletons), is irrelevant because the player cannot feel it.
>What about Eurotruck simulator?
Death Stranding is still mostly walking.
With Eurotruck, I will still need to purchase a truck, and afford gas.
Walking, on the other hand, is free.
Simulators existed before video games, serving as a way to experiment and train at a substantially lower human and capital cost.
Clearly, they provide experiences that are difficult / not economical in real life.
>Death Stranding allows me to fight BTs.
If only Death Stranding could present these challanges to the player more often, instead of padding out the game with walking 80% of the time.
My argument about the abysmally boring combat still stands, though.
>Death Stranding allows me to walk in a post-apocalyptic environment.
That's just walking with a post-apocalyptic movie. Not gameplay.
>Death Stranding is pure ludo / [Insert celebrity here] is amazing.
Not a substitute for gameplay.

last_replies.com: To be fair, you have to have a very high IQ to understand Death Stranding. The gameplay is extremely subtle, and without a solid grasp of the trigger buttons most of the traversal will go over a typical gamer's head. There's also Kojima's nihilistic outlook, which is deftly woven into his writing - his personal philosophy draws heavily from Hollywood movies, for instance. The fans understand this stuff; they have the intellectual capacity to truly appreciate the depths of these references, to realize that they're not just films - they say something deep about LIFE. As a consequence people who dislike Death Stranding truly ARE idiots- of course they wouldn't appreciate, for instance, the meaning behind Amelie's existential catchphrase "Like Mario and Princess 'Beach'" which itself is a cryptic reference to videogame classic, Super Mario Bros. 2. I'm smirking right now just imagining one of those addlepated simpletons scratching their heads in confusion as Kojima's genius unfolds itself on their television screens. What fools... how I pity them. And yes by the way, I DO have a Norman Reedus tattoo. And no, you cannot see it. It's for the ladies' eyes only- And even they have to demonstrate that they're within 5 IQ points of my own (preferably lower) beforehand.

I can honestly say that I've been asked a million times why I play games. And I normally just shrug and say "It's a hobby.", but that's a lie. Because when I'm in game, I'm at home. From the flames of cataclysm to the icy mountains of Tamriel, anywhere I venture, is a place I love and know. My entire life people preach that I could be anything that I wanted to be. But when I told them I wanted to be the captain of a ship, a spaceship, THE spaceship that saves humanity. That I wanted to be Commander Shepard they told me I need to get a grip on reality. And to them to them a grip on a reality means the American dream, working nine to five crammed up in a tiny cubicle
having two-point-five kids, a two story suburban house and a white picket fence. I divorce once, and I'd have debt into my early thirties because I took some bullshit university degree that's suppose to help me in the end.

This isn't reality, this is just a dull outlook on it. Now I understand it's human nature to achieve greatness, but I can do this as Commander Shepard, I don't need a degree. And if I want to go on an adventure I don't ever have to leave the comfort of my home. Yet, people spend an entire salary to travel and I can't help but laugh. I've single-handedly stopped a reign of ancient wyverns from destroying a nation, but before I could do that do I had to:
• Learn their language
• Become a master in Swordsmanship, Smithing, Archery, Defense, Magic, Speech, Hunting and Thieving!

I have my own world at my fingertips, if I screw something up I can rewind time. I can't do that in real life, but when I'm in game I'm free to what I please, when I please, I'm free to enjoy things the way I want to. I can build my own Kingdom and lead my people to freedom because I'm the mind behind the game. I'm the one who enjoys these games.
I am a gamer.
And I always will be.

threads.name: Game UIs for PC Games Only
threads.com:
Hey /v/, so I'm finally digging into the main menu for my game (the pause menu). This is one of the most important menus in a game, especially if it's an RPG. You always see video game menus that were converted from controller to work on PC, but you rarely see it the other way around where a PC-game, mouse and keyboard centric UI are ported to work with consoles.

I have some people on my team that claim that we need to make it with controllers in mind first. However, I don't really care much about controller support and want to make this a PC game through and through. I'm thinking I want to make an interface that's full of information and has keyboard/mouse users in mind, and then I'll just add support for controllers someday after. You could do both at the same time possibly, but you probably won't be able to use either to its full potential otherwise. So I think I'm going to go for MKB.

So all of this said, what are examples of PC games with really good UIs that take advantage of the fact it's on a keyboard/mouse? I'm interested to see if there's really any high budget modern examples. I'm also open to seeing some good UIs from old games as well. I'm just trying to do a little research.

>>618793467
>woah. Amazing, shame about all the thematic elements that had to be lost for a shallow story.
Your argument was that they weren't in the game outright, not about how they were implemented. Don't move the goalpost.

>I can't see them and you can't name them
Fine, I'll bite.

The all encompassing theme of the Xeno series at large, according to Takahashi himself, is the exploration of the relationships between foreign things and people, with each title exploring various societal structures and how humanity persists within them. I believe it's fairly obvious how that relates to Xenoblade 3 given the main party being comprised of soldiers from foreign worlds coming together to stop a greater force that seeks to keep them opposed.

Beyond that, each game in the series is primarily focused on a different outlook on how one should change the world to benefit those around them. XC1 presented a case for allowing those with the will to grasp the future to shape it for themselves, XC2 for using the failings of the past to inform the future, and XC3 for uprooting the status quo for the greater good. There's obviously more to each title than that, and I'm sure I'm missing some of the finer details, but those are the broad-scope arguments of each. Arguments that also encompass the personal plights/outlooks of the three trinity processor cores (Ontos, Pneuma, and Logos) respectively, with 3 obviously rounding them out.

Beyond the wide reaching concepts, themes drawing from Gnosticism, Freudian psychology, philosophy, aforementioned metaphysics, etc. are still present within XC3 in some if not a greater capacity in 3 than past blade entries. The only difference that I believe distinguishes 3's implementation is its relatively reserved nature when the rest were fairly blunt in how they handled such references.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: Games keep coming out but none of them can compare to Death Stranding. The innovation, the atmosphere, the art, the gameplay. Everyone else is giving us a ripoff of a remake of a sequel, while Kojima brought us something that is actually brilliant and original. It's hard to even play games anymore when Death Stranding has revealed all others as absolutely soulless.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Common responses:
>You didn't play the game.
Yes I did.
>Filtered.
Good. I'm not a mouth-breathing Kojima drone.
>Walking simulators are a valid game genre. There are others like it.
Death Stranding is a AAA game with massive hype and marketing surrounding it.
Yet it was never honestly marketed as a walking simulator, because then interest in the game would vanish overnight.
I have enjoyed smaller, indie walking simulators because they were marketed exactly as a walking simulator.
My expectations were appropriately managed.
The games were genuinely relaxing, had engaging puzzles/problems, and were suitably short enough for the player to enjoy without getting bored.
Death Stranding is far too long for a walking game, and fails at both being relaxing and having engaging puzzles/problems.
There's just enough time fall and BTs so you can't relax all the time.
But neither are the difficulties actually challenging.
>It's relaxing!
Time fall and BTs are literally there to ruin your scenic walk.
>It's not just walking! Look there's combat!
You concede the point about Death Stranding being relaxing because combat is, broadly speaking, not relaxing.
The amount of combat events are far outweighed by the sheer amount of walking.
Where there is combat and stealth elements, they are ordinary, derivative, and mediocre at best.
A disappointing observation considering Kojima's earlier work with the Metal Gear series.
I'm increasingly convinced that the success of the Metal Gear series isn't attributed to Kojima.
>Well I like it. Why are you raining on my parade?
It's bullshit that Kojima drones are enabling him to shit out this pretentious crap.
I'm writing this to people still on the fence, who haven't played Death Stranding yet, warning them so they don't get fooled into enjoying a AAA, premium shit, walking simulator.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
More common responses:
>Just turn off online features
And ignore one of the game's main selling points? Nice own goal.
>It's not unusual for films to depict ordinary experiences attainable in real life. Why should video games be any different?
Video games are unique because they are interactive, they have gameplay.
It should therefore be every game designer's prerogative to prioritize fun gameplay before anything else, to fully utilize the medium.
Otherwise the game would be no different from a film - which Death Stranding clearly should have been.
>What about sports games? I can play sports in real life.
Sports games actually do provide the unattainable for most people.
The mechanics of the sport is simplified by reducing complex body motion / hand-eye coordination with keyboard/controller interaction.
The player does not experience fatigue, injury, and can be as strong/fast as the game will allow.
On the other hand, walking is a trivial activity.
The weight of the cargo, or lack of (due to exoskeletons), is irrelevant because the player cannot feel it.
>What about Eurotruck simulator?
Death Stranding is still mostly walking.
With Eurotruck, I will still need to purchase a truck, and afford gas.
Walking, on the other hand, is free.
Simulators existed before video games, serving as a way to experiment and train at a substantially lower human and capital cost.
Clearly, they provide experiences that are difficult / not economical in real life.
>Death Stranding allows me to fight BTs.
If only Death Stranding could present these challanges to the player more often, instead of padding out the game with walking 80% of the time.
My argument about the abysmally boring combat still stands, though.
>Death Stranding allows me to walk in a post-apocalyptic environment.
That's just walking with a post-apocalyptic movie. Not gameplay.
>Death Stranding is pure ludo / [Insert celebrity here] is amazing.
Not a substitute for gameplay.

last_replies.com: To be fair, you have to have a very high IQ to understand Death Stranding. The gameplay is extremely subtle, and without a solid grasp of the trigger buttons most of the traversal will go over a typical gamer's head. There's also Kojima's nihilistic outlook, which is deftly woven into his writing - his personal philosophy draws heavily from Hollywood movies, for instance. The fans understand this stuff; they have the intellectual capacity to truly appreciate the depths of these references, to realize that they're not just films - they say something deep about LIFE. As a consequence people who dislike Death Stranding truly ARE idiots- of course they wouldn't appreciate, for instance, the meaning behind Amelie's existential catchphrase "Like Mario and Princess 'Beach'" which itself is a cryptic reference to videogame classic, Super Mario Bros. 2. I'm smirking right now just imagining one of those addlepated simpletons scratching their heads in confusion as Kojima's genius unfolds itself on their television screens. What fools... how I pity them. And yes by the way, I DO have a Norman Reedus tattoo. And no, you cannot see it. It's for the ladies' eyes only- And even they have to demonstrate that they're within 5 IQ points of my own (preferably lower) beforehand.

threads.com:
What is even the fucking point of games like Hollow Knight, Salt and Sanctuary, Moonscars, etc.? Elden Ring is fully 3d with incredible graphics, heavy atmosphere, amazing combat with depth and variety, and a massive open world with well crafted environments. So why the fuck would I choose to play some shit like Hallow Knight, which is inferior in every fucking way? Look at this screenshot, anyone who has played this game knows when you first see Caelid it's like some "holy fucking SHIT!" moment. Nothing in any 2d game can come remotely close to that visually. Don't even get me started on the combat, Elden Ring having tons of weapons with their own combos and shitloads of skills, compared to some 2d shit game having you spam the same shitty basic attack nonstop the entire game with a few unique skills here and there, against easy ass enemies that barely do shit.

Seriously, if you aren't going to put in the effort to make a fucking 3d game, don't half ass it and make 2d shit instead, it's a waste of time.
